Two students buy the same stock at the same moment.

What's happening?

objectives.description: Understand how stock and bond markets operate and facilitate trillions in daily trading.
Recognize the roles of exchanges, market makers, brokers, and regulators in market function.
Distinguish between market orders and limit orders and when to use each type.
Determine trading costs including bid-ask spreads and understand their long-term impact.

terms.definition: The highest price a buyer is currently willing to pay for a security.
terms.example: This is the price you RECEIVE when selling your shares.

terms.definition: The lowest price a seller is currently willing to accept for a security.
terms.example: This is the price you PAY when buying shares.

terms.definition: The difference between bid and ask prices. A hidden transaction cost!
terms.example: Bid $49.95, Ask $50.05 = Spread of $0.10 per share.

terms.definition: A firm always ready to buy/sell securities, providing liquidity and profiting from spreads.
terms.example: They ensure you can always trade, but the spread is their fee.

leftPanel.title: Matching Buyers with Sellers
paragraphs: When you click "buy" on 10 shares of Apple, your brokerage routes your order to an exchange (NYSE, NASDAQ).
Electronic systems match your buy order with a seller in milliseconds.
Prices are determined by supply and demand‚Äîmore buyers than sellers pushes price up, and vice versa.

highlightBox.text: � You're buying from another investor, not the company. This "secondary market" provides liquidity to convert investments to cash.

content.headerTitle: The Bid-Ask Spread: A Hidden Cost

leftPanel.title: The Cost of Every Trade
paragraphs:
Example Quote:
Bid: $49.95 | Ask: $50.05 | Spread: $0.10

If you buy 100 shares: Pay $5,005 (ask price)
If you immediately sell: Receive $4,995 (bid price)
Loss: $10 just from the spread!

Narrower spreads = more liquid stocks (like Apple: $0.01-$0.03)
Wider spreads = less liquid stocks (small caps: $0.10-$0.50+)

highlightBox.text: ‚ö†Ô∏è "Commission-free" doesn't mean free! Spreads are a real cost on every trade.

rightColumn.title: Limit Order
items: "Buy/sell only at my price or better"
May sit unfilled if price never hit

content.headerTitle: When to Use Each Order Type

layoutData.title: Match Order Type to Situation
paragraphs: Understanding when to use each order type can save you thousands over your investing lifetime.
bulletPoints: Market Order OK: Highly liquid stocks (Apple, Microsoft) with penny spreads. Need immediate execution.
Limit Order Better: Less liquid stocks with wide spreads. You can wait for better price.
Limit Order Essential: Volatile conditions after news. Market open when prices swing wildly.
Pro Tip: Split the spread! If bid is $49.95 and ask is $50.05, place limit at $50.00‚Äîmight save $0.05/share.

keyPoint.text: üéØ No rush? Use limit orders. You're not a day trader‚Äîpatience saves money.

leftPanel.title: The True Cost of Frequent Trading
paragraphs:
Frequent Trader:
100 trades/year √ó $0.15 spread √ó 50 shares
= $750/year in spread costs

Buy-and-Hold Investor:
4 trades/year √ó $0.02 spread √ó 200 shares
= $16/year in spread costs
Over 30 years at 7% returns, that $734 annual difference compounds to $69,000 in lost wealth!

highlightBox.text: � This is why Warren Buffett says his favorite holding period is "forever."

layoutData.title: What Every Number Means
paragraphs: Stock quotes contain critical information for making informed trading decisions:
bulletPoints: Last Price: Price of most recent trade (what you see in headlines)
Bid/Ask: Current buy/sell prices. The prices YOU'LL actually pay or receive.
Volume: Shares traded today. High volume = more liquid, narrower spreads.
Day Range: Today's high and low prices. Shows current volatility.
52-Week Range: High/low over past year. Context for current price.
Market Cap: Total company value. Large-cap = typically more stable.

keyPoint.text: üìä High volume + narrow spread = easy to trade. Low volume + wide spread = use limit orders!

leftPanel.title: When Markets Are Open
paragraphs:
Regular Trading Hours:
9:30 AM - 4:00 PM Eastern Time
Monday through Friday (except holidays)

Pre-Market: 4:00 AM - 9:30 AM
After-Hours: 4:00 PM - 8:00 PM
(Extended hours have wider spreads, less liquidity, more risk!)
Orders placed when closed queue until next open‚Äîprices may be very different!

highlightBox.text: ‚è∞ Weekend panic? Your market order won't execute until Monday at potentially a VERY different price.

scenario.name: Sofia: The Power of Limit Orders
paragraphs: Sofia wanted to buy 6 shares of an ETF trading around $125. She checked the quote: Bid $124.96, Ask $125.04.
Instead of using a market order at $125.04, she placed a limit order at $125.00‚Äîsplitting the spread. After 17 minutes, her order executed when the price dipped.
Savings: $0.24 on this trade. Over 20 trades/year √ó $2 average savings √ó 40 years at 7% = $8,500 extra wealth just from using limit orders!

scenario.name: Marcus: Market Hours Lesson
paragraphs: Marcus read bad news about his stock Sunday evening. Panicking, he placed a market order to sell at the displayed price of $85.00.
Problem: Markets were closed until Monday 9:30 AM. His order sat in queue. Overnight, more bad news emerged.
Monday open: Stock gapped down to $78.50. His market order executed at that price‚Äî$325 less than he expected. A limit order at $84 would have protected him.

takeaways.title: Spreads Are Real Costs
takeaways.description: You pay the ask when buying, receive the bid when selling. This spread is a hidden cost on every single trade.

takeaways.title: Limit Orders Save Money
takeaways.description: Use limit orders for illiquid stocks, volatile conditions, or when you're not in a rush. Split the spread!

takeaways.title: Know Market Hours
takeaways.description: US markets: 9:30 AM - 4:00 PM Eastern, weekdays. Orders placed when closed execute at next open‚Äîpotentially at very different prices.

takeaways.title: Trading Costs Compound
takeaways.description: Frequent trading erodes returns through spreads. Buy-and-hold usually beats active trading for individual investors.
